Judge Bolin remained an advocate for children and families until the end of her life. A powerful legacy. #BlackHistoryMonth https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/10/obituaries/10bolin.html

But for Judge Bolin, it was a good fit. She avoided her judicial robes to make children feel more at ease, and tried to show ‚Äúa broad sympathy for human suffering.‚Äù
 
She worked with First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt to desegregate children‚Äôs spaces and end juvenile crime.

As a family court judge she was dedicated her life to children. That's a tough job. I remember during my own early career, before I became a police officer, when as a social worker it was often difficult to see a child in a tough situation and have limited tools to help.

"Jane Bolin made history over and over."
 
She was the first Black woman to graduate from Yale Law School. The first Black woman to join the New York City Bar Association. She saw the barriers put up ahead of her, and broke through them.
https://www.cbs46.com/black-history-month-jane-bolin-first-black-woman-to-graduate-from-yale-law-school/article_6ab2c399-8ff7-5bac-81c6-a5bd7d3a9e1e.html

Jane Bolin was America's first Black female judge, the first in a long road towards equal justice under the law.
 
She once said, ‚Äúthose gains we have made were never graciously and generously granted. We have had to fight every inch of the way.‚Äù #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FKrSqagXsAUlQgW.jpg

The letter we sent to the White House is simply asking for an investigation to determine if any of these agencies are acting unscrupulously.
This is wrong, and if it is indeed happening, America's nurses are getting caught in the crossfire between staffing agencies and the potentially exorbitant rates they charge hospitals.
